Test your knowledge..."Hot Patootie, bless my - _____." Act out your favorite character in Wild And Untamed Thing. Dance The Time Warp, and enjoy erotic trivia game fun..."guaranteed to thrill you, chill you and fulfill you!"

Contains: 250 trivia cards, 1,231 Questions, score pad, oversized die, and rules.

20867.name: Dimension 0
20867.description:
Summary
Japanese trading card game designed by Nakamura Satoshi (Fairy Tale, Yuhodo). The game is somewhat like Magic: the Gathering, and somewhat like Duel Masters. Units move and fight on a 3x3 grid. The game is set in a mixed science/fantasy setting, with both metal robots and dragons. Depth of game play is claimed to be one of its features.

20868.name: Starmada X: Brigade
20868.description:
Starmada X: Brigade is a source book for The Universal Game of Starship Combat, providing background and starship designs for seven different factions, each taken from Brigade Models' excellent line of starship miniatures.

The 72 different ship classes included in this book have each been designed by players of Starmada. They present a wide variety of philosophies and strategies, illustrating the flexibility of the most comprehensive starship construction system available in any space combat wargame.

Brigade includes the complete rules for Starmada X, allowing you to start blasting your opponents into just so much space dust right away!

20869.name: Iron Stars: The Merchant War
20869.description:
The Merchant War is the first supplement for Iron Stars. Here, you will find much to expand upon the basic Iron Stars game, including:

* A detailed history of the Merchant War of 1908-1909 between the United Kingdom and Austria-Hungary;
* The introduction of fast attack craft and His Majesty's Space Station Celestial Queen;
* One dozen new ship designs, including the German Äthermarine and Austro-Hungarian Sternmarine;
* Six new scenarios covering actions of the Merchant War;
* More information about Martians by the best-known chronicler of the Invasion, H. G. Wells;
* Additional rules for combat, including crew casualties and searchlights;
* New special equipment, such as machine guns and poison gas;
* Errata for the original Iron Stars rulebook; and
* Rules for including freighters and Q-ships in your games.

In addition, The Merchant War includes counters for the ships involved in the scenarios provided and an additional mine template.

20870.name: Adjugé
20870.description:
Become the richest collector!
Six rare objects are for sale at the auction, no one knows their real value.

20871.name: Babylonia
20871.description:
From the publisher:

A points scoring game of ‘facing capture’, ‘waiting capture’ ‘void captures’ & ‘capture proper’ for 2 to 8 player’s played on an classically designed, yet attractively different, checkered board where war is fought IN every direction & FROM every direction!

A Classic in Waiting, in Tradition, and in Style, Babylonia™ is a social 2 to 8 players points scoring capture game, where the winner is the player with the most point at the end of the game after deductions have been made. In this game the player’s men are called ‘Zealots’.

Taking turns, a move is to lay your Zealot on the board, then totaling your scores, if any, for that turn - and that’s about it really, but don't be misled; from humble beginnings the whole board will soon have you on your toes! So watch out. You have been warned!!!

20872.description:
Pizza Box Football's 32-Team Expansion Game is based on the 2004-2005 season. All 32 teams are modeled after their strengths and weaknesses. How will you shut down Indy's powerful passing? Penetrate Pittsburgh's stalwart defense? Slow Atlanta's running QB? Can anybody beat New England?

The expansion also adds 3 additional play calls for the offense and 3 additional play call for the defense. Beware of the defense's blitz! Watch out for the screen pass!

The expansion comes in its own envelope, allowing it to store easily inside your existing Pizza Box Football game. The envelope holds the cards for the 32 teams as well as the expansion play sequence cards.

Expands:

Pizza Box Football
20872.name: Pizza Box Football Expansion

20873.description:
SJG Game # 7107

8.5" x 11" book which crossed the Champions and Car Wars systems. Had rules for auto dueling in Champions as well as super powers in Car Wars. Helicopter construction and combat rules were first introduced here.
20873.name: Autoduel Champions

20874.description:
Street Fighter - An Auto-Combat Solo Module (#AV-1005)

8.5" x 11" book was the fifth AutoVentures Car Wars supplement by Aaron Allston. In 1985, Task Force Games took over publishing this line of supplements.
20874.name: Street Fighter

20875.description:
The Gauntlet - An Auto-Combat Solo Module (#AV-1006)

8.5" x 11" book was the sixth AutoVentures Car Wars supplement by Aaron Allston.
20875.name: The Gauntlet

20876.description:
From the package:

"Looking for adventure? Trouble? A route across the bandit-ravaged countryside of America, 2039? Or just a safe truck stop?

Autoduel America puts the world of 2039 right at your fingertips. Two beautiful 23" x 35" full-color maps detail the North American continent, including road conditions for the major interstate, U.S., and state highways; nuclear zones; truck stops; cities; fortress towns; ruins; military bases; national forests and parks; state and national capitals; no dueling zones and lawless areas. Use them as posters or as game aids for Car Wars or GURPS Autoduel campaigns."
20876.name: Autoduel America

20877.name: La carga de la Brigada Ligera: Batalla de Balaclava
20877.description:
Wargame published by NAC Española, "wargame Series", in little format. It represents the Battle of Balaclava in 1854. An expeditionary mixed force (French and British) with 56,000 men and 5,000 Turkish began the invasion of the Crimean Peninsula. Their main objective was Sevastopol.

- Board: 24 x 38 cms.
- 112 counters.
- Rule book (in Spanish).

Juego de simulacion belica publicado por NAC Española. Recrea la batalla de Balaclava, con la famosa carga de la Caballeria Ligera. El juego viene en una minicaja de 20 x 13 cms.

20878.name: Whoa Nellie
20878.description: Girls and Boys of all ages are high in the saddle. Everyone rides in the state fair, but only one will win the Gold Cup. Choose the right move, make the most jumps, collect your flag, and ride back to collect your prize! Whoa Nellie entertains players who enjoy horses and rewards players who like the challenge of planning ahead. Whoa! This is fun! Climb on!

20880.name: Harry Potter and The Goblet of Fire Quidditch Dice Game
20880.description:
From the rules: Roll the dice and place them on the Quidditch Pitch to earn goals and catch the Golden Snitch, or to block your opponent from scoring. The first player to "catch" the Golden Snitch ends the match, and the player with the most Goal Points wins!

Components:
1 trunk (travel-size game case)
1 score board & die holder
1 Quaffle Die (Red 12-Sided)(*)
2 Bludger Dice (Black 12-Sided)(*)
1 Golden Snitch Die (Gold 6-Sided)
1 Keeper Die (Black 6-Sided)
4 Goal Dice (Blue 6-Sided)
2 Quaffle Score Markers (1 Blue, 1 Red)
2 Golden Snitch Score Markers (1 Blue, 1 Red)

(*) All 3 12-sided dice in this game are actually 12-sided D6's (meaning they are numbered from 1-6 twice).

boardgamehonor: 2006 Golden Geek Best Light / Party Game Nominee
20881.name: You Must Be an Idiot!
20881.description: Clever trivia game with a twist. Each round, a rotating "genius" chooses a question for the other players to answer. One or more of those players might be randomly (and secretly) designated as "idiots", in which case they must write an incorrect answer. There are several ways to score points: get the answer right when you're not an idiot; correctly accuse an idiot; avoid getting found out when you're an idiot; or trick others into accusing you when you're not an idiot. These scoring dynamics lead to plenty of interesting decisions, making this much more interesting and tactical than your average trivia game.

20882.name: Conservation
20882.description:
Players are attempting to gain "tricks" of three bird cards: a male, female and young of the same species. The game uses a deck of cards, comprising: 75 bird cards (3 of each species), 6 Hazards, 6 Protection cards and 1 Appeal card.

6 cards are dealt to each player at the start of the game. The players then pick a card from the deck (or discard pile) and then play. Sets of species are built (Male, then Female, then Young) and a completed set forms a trick and is put to one side. Sets are built up in the spaces along the edge of the board facing the player; the species has to go in the appropriate habitat (as indicated on the card).

Partial sets can be protected by Protection cards and destroyed by Hazard cards. The Appeal card allows you to take one card from another player, in return for the Appeal card, which can then be used again by its new owner. Some of the species are "Rare Species". Completing these sets gains the player the appropriate counter.

To end the game you have to get a certain number of sets of species, with the rare ones counting for 2 or 3, depending on the value on the counter. Points are then totaled, with each species set being worth 50 points, with the appropriate multiplier (x2 or x3) for the "Rare" species, and cards in front of each player (but not yet in completed sets) being worth 10 points each.

20883.name: Sticks and Stones
20883.description: Sticks and Stones is a trading game, where 12 different resources and one club are traded between players. Players advance their resource production by purchasing more sticks and stones through resource sets of 3 or 6 respectively. Fires can be built for sets of 9. The first person to build 4 fires wins. The player in control of the club gets to make the rules and also gets to go first.

20884.description:
Another game to play SuDoKu - a kind of crossword puzzle from Japan.

In the beginning you have to copy one of many tasks from a small card to the washable boardgame by using a marker.

Now you can start the game.
Every player has 30 seconds to find numbers that match in the cells. The other players have, first to control the time and second, the correctness of the numbers.
To write the numbers on the board, every player uses his own marker in a different color.

After finishing the puzzle, every player has to sum up the numbers he had put in - the player with the highest sum wins.
20884.name: SUDOKU: Das Brettspiel

20885.name: Fang Bang
20885.description:
Competitors wear crazy face masks while trying to pop opponents' balloon snakes with their own balloon snake.

Snakes consist of incredibly long, thin balloons (the type you twist & model) with a plastic snake head mask secured to one end by an elastic band. Each snake head has a 'tongue' with an abrasive surface which is used to burst the inflated balloons.

20886.name: Hocus Pocus
20886.description:
Unusual game from Transogram that really relies on components which glow in the dark for gameplay mechanics. Comes in a very large box (17" x 12" x 8").

The game consists of a large hat with spring platform, four plastic rabbits (three of which glow in the dark), a large silk Hocus Pocus handkerchief, a wand with four detachable tips and many rings that are the game's 'currency' which also glow in the dark and must be worn on the fingers of players.

When a player has won enough rings during gameplay (they must be wearing 10 rings BEFORE their turn) they get the opportunity to insert the tip of the wand into the hat & release the spring, causing the rabbits to pop up in the air. This may or may not occur, depending on whether the correct wand tip is chosen.

The first player to make the rabbits fly out of the hat is the winner.

Although this game can be played in the light (by pretending the black rabbit is 'invisible') it is much more atmospheric and exciting in the dark.

20887.name: Total Football
20887.description:
Totalfootball is a Football (soccer) strategy game. It consists of a hard plastic carrying case which is, when opened, the football field. Each player has a team of 11 players, including the keeper, just as in the real game. The rules are an abstract version of the real rules, and in order to execute the actions, dice are used for details.

The game is published by a company from Kazachstan (Mind Game inc.) and several other Kazachstan companies have aided with this production. Besides a rulebook in a lot of languages also a CD-Rom with the game rules is included.

20888.description:
An LPS bonus mini-game, Assault On Narvik is a simulation of the ground, sea and air battles that raged around the far northern port of Narvik in Norway during the spring of 1940. Gamers can take both games and compare just how much each side learned about amphibious operations in the three years that separated the two battles.

The game has an 11" by 17" map, 95 half-inch counters, 2 pages of charts and tables and 10 pages of rules. The game covers the Allied landings just after the Royal Navy went in and blew out of the water the German destroyer flotilla (that had just landed their troops).

The game uses a clever mechanic that ties in units' Fatigue Levels whenever they perform any sort of operation (move, attack, defend, retreat, you get the picture). The terrain and weather were so inhospitable that units can get worn down pretty quick, and players have to be thinking ahead to win the game.

Rules cover formation integrity, air support (mostly the Luftwaffe), limited intelligence, combined arms, even an armistice and/or internment of German units in Sweden. There is a lot packed into this little game, and we're very happy to be able to "shoe-horn it in."
20888.name: Assault on Narvik

boardgameimplementation: Great War at Sea 2: The North & Baltic Seas
20889.description:
From the Avalanche Press website:

History’s best-known naval battle was just one part of the ongoing four-year struggle to control the seas around Germany’s coasts. If the German High Seas Fleet could catch and destroy a portion of the much larger British Grand Fleet, the blockade suffocating Imperial Germany might finally be broken.

Great War at Sea: Jutland is an extensively updated version of the earlier GWAS Vol. II: The North and Baltic Seas published in 1998. It covers not only the signature battle, but also the many other sorties of the High Seas Fleet like the Scarborough, Lowestoft and Gorleston Raids, the Battle of Dogger Bank and Helgoland Bight.

Like all games in the Great War at Sea series, this one is packed with scenarios. Along with the operations in the North Sea, the game also includes the bitterly-fought naval war in the Baltic Sea. Here the roles are reversed, with the smaller Imperial Russian Navy aggressively seeking an advantage against the larger German forces. The Russian cruiser raids are all covered, as well as the climactic Battle of Moon Sound.

The scenario book includes not only more than 40 scenarios, it’s packed with the background information about the ships, the men and the battles.

The map covers the North and Baltic Seas, as well as the waters around the British Isles; it’s a bit larger than the map in the previous edition. The smaller navies of the region are all represented as well: Sweden, Norway, Denmark, the Netherlands.

But it’s the major powers that get most of the ships. The Royal Navy is huge, with ships ranging from ancient paddle-driven minesweepers to modern battle cruisers like Repulse and Renown. Famous ships like the battleships Dreadnought and Iron Duke, the inaptly-named battle cruiser Invincible, and early aircraft carriers like Engadine and Argus are all here.

The German High Seas Fleet has all the ships that challenged England, from the tiny coast defense ship Siegfried up to the huge battleships Sachsen and Württemburg. The Germans have zeppelins and submarines to help redress the balance somewhat, but it will take skilled play to overcome Britain’s sea dogs.

Russia has modern dreadnoughts, but will depend on her armored cruisers and a squadron of older battleships for most missions.

As with other games in the series, the tactical map is a generic blue field of hexagons, used to resolve surface combat. There, ships maneuver and fight using their gunnery and torpedo factors. Each player rolls a number of dice according to the ship’s capabilities, hitting on a result of 6. Gunnery and torpedo damage tables give the results: ships can suffer damage to engines, hull or armament.


32 miles/sea zone campaign scale
420 1-inch counters, 420 1/2-inch counters
34" x 22" operational map
24" x 24" tactical map
16 page rules, 128 page scenario book
20889.name: Great War at Sea: Jutland

20890.name: Im Zeichen des Sechsecks: Klaus Teuber & Die Siedler von Catan
20890.description: A book detailing the development of the Settlers of Catan game, background history about Klaus Teuber etc. It also includes a 15-page appendix answering rule questions.

20893.name: The Playing Card Kit
20893.description:
"Two decks and a book of games for all the family."

This set includes two decks of regular playing cards, and a 144 page book with rules for card games. The table of contents is organized as follows:
1. History of Playing Cards
2. Rules of Play
3. Children's Games (12)
4. Social Games (22)
5. Games of Skill (12)
6. Gambling Games (14)
7. Solitaire Games (10)
8. Further Reading & Index

20894.name: Sound Off
20894.description:
Two teams attempt to reach the end of the board by acting out. When a team lands on a space, the actor on that team (it changes every turn) must act out what's on the card in 30 seconds or less. The catch is, they *must* use sound - the rules include a provision where if the other team catches them not using sound, they lose credit for a right answer. Only sound effects - no speaking - are allowed however.

The board spaces are as follows: Action Reaction, which is a long form charade such as "passing gas and blaming it on the dog." Famous Expressions is usually a cliche or popular phrase. People, Places & Things is self explanatory.

The fourth category is "Hot Spot." Five items are on this card, and the team gets 60 seconds. If the actor can convey three out of the five, they get credit and continue to roll and move. Getting all five earns a "Safe & Sound" card. This can also be earned via its own space on the board. Safe & Sound allows an actor to pass a charade - but only once on a given turn, regardless of the amount of S&S cards they have.

Some spaces are designated all play by an arrow. The finish space of the game is an All-Play Hot Spot. Whichever team gets the majority of the five items in 60 seconds gets credit - and if you're on the team on the final Hot Spot space, that means you're the winner.

20895.name: Polly Pottwal
20895.description:
Try to catch as many fish as you can with the help of Paula.
On a Magnificent wooden board the whale is placed right in the middle. You have to use Paula on the edge of the board (wooden Pawn) and a string (connected to the whale) to catch the fish. This is much more difficult as you think, because you have to act under pressure of time.

There is an expert rule: Throw a die and catch only the fish of this certain color.

The author Robert F. Watson is better known on the BGG as robbirob.

20896.name: Tiltin' Milton
20896.description:
DON'T TILT MILTON WHILE HE'S SNOOZIN' ...
... I'LL BE WINNIN', YOU"LL BE LOSIN'

so goes the rant on the box of this typical late sixties plastic offering from Ideal.

The object is to place as many objects on Milton as possible without causing him to topple out of his hammock. Objects come in pairs - 10 large objects (e.g. bird nest, hat) and 10 smaller 'accessory' objects which pair off with the relevant larger object (eggs, feather etc). The first player places one large object on Milton & their turn ends. The next person to play places the relevant accessory object and then also another large object on Milton & their turn ends. Play continues in this manner until Milton topples out of his hammock; the player who causes this event to occur is eliminated from the game. All objects are removed from Milton, who is replaced in his hammock & play commences again until only one player, the winner, remains.

20897.name: Miss World Game
20897.description:
Players select their contestant from a pool of four supplied small dolls, complete with swimsuit. A robe is purchased for each and play commences with Miss World contestants circling the board on their 'World Tour', earning money for various tasks. When a contestant thinks they have accrued enough money (points) they may elect to parade on the Miss World catwalk stage. Each space on the stage costs points (money) and any contestant who runs out of points is eliminated.

The first player to reach the Golden Spotlight on the stage is awarded the winner's crown and the title of Miss World 'to the enthusiastic applause of all beaten contestants' - so sayeth the rules!

20898.name: Monopoly: United States Marines
20898.description:
From the website:

USMC Monopoly® Game an Exciting Salute to Bravery, Commitment, and Patriotism! 6 Unique Collectible Pewter Tokens! - This has to be one of the most original ways you and your family can salute the United States Marine Corps - a super-exciting USMC Monopoly® game! Be the first to fight as you buy, sell and trade the most prized assets of the U.S. Marines. It's your chance to control and command the branch of the armed forces that has never - in its entire history - retreated in war!
Brought to you by USAopoly, this exciting Monopoly board game has players vying to own the battle ready AV-8B Harrier II, CH-46E Sea Knight Helicopter, EA-6B Prowler and much more! And each player gets to choose from 6 unique collectible pewter tokens: Assault Amphibian Vehicle, HMMWV, AV-8B Harrier II, Helmet, Boots, or the USMC Initials. Get in the action, and order now!
MONOPOLY® ™ & ©2005 Hasbro.

This USMC Monopoly® game from USAopoly features:
From the Monopoly American Classics series! An exciting and innovative version of the classic Monopoly game, designed to honor the United States Marine Corps
Comes with 6 collectible pewter tokens: Assault Amphibian Vehicle, HMMWV, AV-8B Harrier II, Helmet, Boots, and USMC Initials
Board, playing and packaging showcase dynamic artwork and graphics of Marines on parade and in action
For 2 - 6 players, ages 8 and up
Box measures 20" W x 1.25" H x 10" D

20899.name: Settlers of Catan: Rockman Edition
20899.description:
Perhaps the only Euro-game to have a huge following in Japan, its popularity has spawned the Rockman Edition of Settlers of Catan. Rockman - known in North America as Megaman - is a well known video game character around the world, and the number of games in the Rockman line continues to be churned out until today.

Belongs to the Catan Series.

20900.description:
Another great children's game from Ravensburger, this one getting your dinosaur (one of four to choose from) past the volcanos, across the stone bridge, through the swamps to the feeding grounds. Last dino standing wins.
As with all Ravensburger games, this one has outstanding components. The dinosaurs are plastic and nicely detailed. One of the hazards is a nice sized plastic boulder. And, the box bottom is part of the gameboard. As usual, Ravensburger makes a game that should make US Publishers hang their heads in shame.
20900.name: Dinosaurs: The Game of Survival

20901.name: Xtreme Zombie Hunter
20901.description:
From the publisher:

Xtreme Zombie Hunter is a comedic table-top miniatures game compatible with all 25mm miniatures of Zombies and the personality types that might hunt them. Set in a fictitious modern day America where Zombies are real and hunting them on national TV has become all the rage! XZH delivers a simple system, which is character driven to encourage replayability, full of laughs and can be enjoyed by 1 or more players. XZH lets you experience the hysterical nature of a B style Zombie movie with a twist.

DEAD LINK
Home Page: http://www.xtremezombiehunter.com/

20902.name: Who is Who
20902.description: Players are taking each others identities and have to find them out by asking questions to each other.

20903.name: I Love the 80s Board Game
20903.description: Players group together up to 4 teams. Each team have to answer questions regarding trivia from different years (80 to 89) sometimes by drawing or acting out the answers, winning a token for each year they answer correctly. Categories include TV, Music, Movie, Sports and a category on fads (products, toys, news and events). The first team to collect 10 tokens, one for each year, wins the game.

20904.description: A game based on the TV program. The object of the game is "to be the first player to travel all the space orbits, collecting the six different colored pieces to complete a TV screen."
boardgameversion: Parker Brothers Ludwig von Drake Edition
20904.name: Walt Disney's Wonderful World of Color Game

20905.name: StockItToYa!
20905.description: This is a game where you attempt to get the most money at the end of the game. You purchase stocks throughout the game, and when all of the stock for a company has been purchased, the stock gets sold. You get a bonus if you are the first to sell the stock in a company.

20906.description:
Nature of the Beast Farm vs Forest is a witty, gritty expandable card game that focuses on recruiting animals and strategic control of your playing field. The first player to gain control of their entire field wins.

Players recruit animals, promote leaders, purchase equipment, find locations, enlist legendary animals, and befriend human allies. Players also keep track of two tallies during the game: Favor and Fury. Favor indicates how much 'pull' you have with humanity. Fury indicates how much of a threat humanity sees you as. Fury is gained by attacking your opponents. Gaining Fury can allow you to take advantage of sinister 'Dark Nature' cards, but gaining too much can eliminate you from the game.

This Battle Box features two 70-card faction decks: Farm and Forest.
Farm animals are well-balanced and know how to take advantage of Dark Nature cards. Forest animals have little interaction with humanity, but are very capable fighters.

Integrates with:

Nature of the Beast: City vs. Suburb
Nature of the Beast: Prairie vs. Polar
20906.name: Nature of the Beast: Farm vs. Forest

20907.description:
Nature of the Beast: City vs Suburb is a witty, gritty expandable card game that focuses on recruiting animals and strategic control of your playing field. The first player to gain control of their entire field wins.

Players recruit animals, promote leaders, purchase equipment, find locations, enlist legendary animals, and befriend human allies. Players also keep track of two tallies during the game: Favor and Fury. Favor indicates how much 'pull' you have with humanity. Fury indicates how much of a threat humanity sees you as. Fury is gained by attacking your opponents. Gaining Fury can allow you to take advantage of sinister 'Dark Nature' cards, but gaining too much can eliminate you from the game.

This Battle Box features two 70-card faction decks: City and Suburb.
City animals are tough and maintain close ties with humanity. Suburb animals are not the largest but they are cunning.

Integrates with:

Nature of the Beast: Farm vs. Forest
Nature of the Beast: Prairie vs. Polar
20907.name: Nature of the Beast: City vs. Suburb

20908.name: Millennium Mania 2000
20908.description:
Description :
You can win by being the biggest trivia buff in the group or by providing the best bluffs. If you convince the other players that your bogus answer to a question is right, you gain the advantage.

20909.name: The 400
20909.description:
"The 400" Game - "The Aristocrat of Games"
Manufactured by Morris Systems Publishing Company
Copyright 1933

"Know 400 pertinent facts about a subject and you will have laid the foundation to become master of it".

Game comes with:
8 32-page question and answer books,
6 score pads with instructions,
1 spinner.

The question and answer books are in the following topics:

Riddles
Etiquette
World Events
Love and Marriage
American History
Famous Sayings
Foods and Cooking
Spelling (National Spelling Bee Series)

Bears the 1933 National Recovery Act (NRA) Eagle Emblem "We do our part"
on the box front and spinner box.

20911.name: Opiumkrieg 1839-42
20911.description:
From Spielbox . . .

In Opiumkrieg 1839-42 (The Opium War 1839-42), the goal is to be at the right place at the right time and then do the right thing. On the eve of the first Opium War, the players sail their junks through the China Sea and buy silk, spices, porcelain or tea from the various harbors. These wares are sold for a heavy profit in the canton where the English freighters are. But the freighters also bring a trading good with them, one out of India that is worth much gold in the harbors along the sea: Opium! The only catch – dealing in Opium is punishable by death. Each player can choose in this game: a long life, or get rich quick. After war breaks out, the needs of the dealers change on a daily basis, forcing flexibility: A harbor that might have been shut yesterday is now open again, where Opium trafficking might be punished heavily today, tomorrow the English might allow it again. The historic events of the time are also included and have an affect on the way the game goes. And yet, there’s still enough variety in the game to make it play out differently each time and allow the players to influence the game in many ways!

20912.name: Sticks & Straws
20912.description: Take as much part of the board, by placing straws in different sizes. The straws are randomized by a dice. Straws can also be taken away if they are not part of an enclosed area.

20913.name: Hold'em-opoly
boardgamepublisher: Late for the Sky Production Company
boardgameversion: Late for the Sky Production Company edition
20913.description: Love poker and real estate trading games? Play both, together! Buy property, pay rent or trade in for a casino. When a player lands on the "Play Hold'Em" space, everybody plays a hand of the popular poker game! Play it safe...or go "all in." There's "no limit" to the fun!

20915.name: 18Kaas
20915.description:
The gameshop 'de Joker' in Utrecht, Netherlands, released 18kaas, an 1830 style 18xx-game in Holland (different from Rob & Paul's 1839 and different from Theo Jansma's version), available in fold-able or hardboard and mounted map style, party proof version (1830: Railways & Robber Barons components required). In 2004 another 100 copies were available.

Though this uses components of 1830 this is not an expansion, but is a separate standalone game.

20916.name: Beneluxreise
20916.description: Like Deutschlandreise, Beneluxreise is a predecessor to "Journey Through Europe". Players try to optimize their route to visit six randomly dealt places in The Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg.

20917.name: Monopoly: Boy Scouts of America
20917.description:
(from bsa-gyc.org):

The world's best-loved board game now celebrates 95 years of strong Scouting values, leadership, and fun! Monopoly®: Boy Scouts of America is played just like the original game, but now features a custom board, cards, money, and pewter playing tokens, including a campaign hat, pocketknife, Scoutmaster cup, Boy Scout sign, flashlight, and Yucca backpack. This officially licensed Monopoly game is great fun for the pack, troop, team, family, and friends. A perfect gift for anyone in Scouting.

20919.description: Mama Duck's chicks can't listen and swim without precaution on the river. Mama Duck now has to catch them! Each player's three chicks try to enjoy their freedom as long as possible. The player who last has a free chick wins.
20919.name: Kleine Ausreißer

20920.description:
Candle Quest is a quick set-collection, auction and money-management game in which you buy/sell/auction cards in order to be the first to collect the entire set of candles necessary to light your Menorah.

On your turn, you either flip over a card from the draw pile, then buy, sell, or auction the card; or loot a card from a personal discard pile. The auction starts with you and goes once around but does not come back to you. If you win the auction, you pay the bank; if another player wins, they pay you and take the candle. In addition to candles, the deck includes unlit candles that you must pay off, but which can be used to pay off other unlit candles or loot candles. The deck also includes dancing candles that are wild, and can be used in place of any color.

In the basic game, the first player to collect all eight differently colored candles wins. In the advanced game, the player with the highest score at game's end wins. Candle Quest includes a junior variant for ages five and six that removes auctions and discard pile purchases and changes unlit candles so that they can be used to steal a candle from another player.

Candle Quest is a re-theme of It's Alive! with a new publisher and artist; while It's Alive! was a re-theme of the original self-published 2005 version of Candle Quest which was called The Menorah Game.

While the theme features a Menorah related to the Jewish holiday of Hanukkah, there is no religious content in the game.

What's In The Box?:

• One full color 9-page Rules booklet
• 60 Candle cards
• 5 player screens
• 54 Shekel coins
• One bright red, 9 1/4" x 5 7/8" Standard cardboard VPG game box
• One beautiful box cover sleeve
• One "Wipes-A-Lot" napkin
• One charcoal desiccant packet

Reimplemented by (and reimplements)


It's Alive!
20920.name: Candle Quest

20921.name: Turncoats
20921.description:
From the publisher's website:

Turncoats is a game of espionage where allegiances can shift at any time during conflict. Players must outsmart their opponent and manipulate the neutral force (which both players have control over) to win.

This fast-paced game combines strategy, luck and ingenuity to create a game that is fun and intriguing for people of all ages. The games concept is roughly based on the idea of a military conflict where two warring factions must manage the effect of a third force which can be influenced by either side. The French and Indian war is an example of a conflict similar to what players will encounter in Turncoats.

20922.description:
It's charades with an exciting, fun and frantic twist. To start, players divide into two or three teams. Each team moves to a different corner of the room or even to different rooms if space allows. now, one member from each team goes to the host who opens the first door on the specially-designed game console to reveal the first charade. The players run back to their teams and act out the charade. As soon as a team member guesses the charade correctly, they run to the host to get the second charade as displayed in the game console. The first team to get all 7 charades wins.

Traditional Charades also included in this game. The game also includes all you need to play traditional charades. Teams move along the game board and land on the seven different categories. Take a card, turn the timer over and start acting out the charade.

Contents:

Charades game console
Double-sided charade cards with over 2000 charades
Gameboard
Sand timer
Movers
Team markers
Game die
Category Tokens
Instructions
20922.name: Running Charades

20923.name: Dive-Opoly
20923.description:
Dive-Opoly is a monopoly clone, replacing Jail with the Hyperbaric Chamber and other properties with dive related businesses. It was published by Scuba Tool with part of the proceeds going to Divers Alert Network (DAN), a non-profit agency dedicated to assisting in education, research, and medical aid to divers throughout the world. The following descriptions come from the game's enclosed instructions.

Object: To become the richest diver from the buying, selling, renting, and trading of scuba related businesses.

Equipment: A game board, 2 dice, tokens, huts and villages, title-deeded cards, Treasure Chest and Explorer cards, and Dive-Opoly money.

For 2-5 divers, Ages 8 and up.

20924.name: The Guinness Game of Records
20924.description: From box: It couldn't be easier to play. Make an educated guess for questions such as "how many letters has the longest place name in Australia?" or "what is the height of the largest recorded wave?". the player who comes closest to the correct answer after two guesses takes the lead.

20925.name: Splittin Infinitives
20925.description:
Splittin Infinitives is a space-strategy board game where each player takes command of an entire race and attempts to conquer the galaxy by military force, colonial expansion, superior technology, underhanded politics, or any combination of the above.

The board is made up of space-tiles each with a different geography laid out randomly, and each player has their own space fleet and starting technology. A technology deck describes the various technological advances players can get. Older races begin with more tech, younger races can acquire more.

The beginning of the game is primarily exploration and colonization using the star-fleet, dealing with random anomalies in space such as black holes, or space-pirates. Once players make 1st contact, then military force and star fleets, and the political deck, come into play.

The winner is the player with the most colonies on the board when the last planet in the galaxy is colonized. Planets are also drawn from a random deck, each with different difficulty ratings, mineral wealth and population maxima.

Splittin Infinitives is suitable for an afternoon's or evening's gaming. The various decks give variety, and keep it light-hearted, while the base allows for strategic serious play. The rules are simple enough to fit on one page, and it can be played right out of the box.

20926.name: Octobuzzy
20926.description:
How to play
Pick one of the tools either oar tweezer or spoon
Spin the ship's wheel
Steal the treasure shown on the wheel. the treasure must be picked up with the chosen tool. If Octobuzzy eye's light up or the buzzer sounds the treasure must be returned and play passes to the next player.
A turn ends when a treasure is stolen without Octobuzzy's eyes lighting up or buzzer sounding.
Spin again if treasure shown has already been stolen by another player.
Lose a turn if treasure shown has already been stolen by yourself.
The winner is the first player to steal 4 different treasures

Same style as Operation

20927.name: The Mayor of Hooverville
20927.description:
It’s October 1931 in Seattle Washington, and you’ve had a tough couple of years. The Stock Market crash of ’29 brought on hard times. You lost your job last year when the lumber mill shut down. Nobody’s hiring. The local bank where you kept your money saved made loans to those businesses that were shutting down. Depositors panicked and there was a run. The bank went into receivership, and your savings were wiped out. With no job and no savings you couldn’t make your house payment, and your mortgage was foreclosed on. Like millions of Americans you find yourself jobless, penniless, homeless.

Down by the Port, on the site of the old shipyard, some men are gathering supplies for winter: cardboard boxes, tar paper, firewood. You have decided to join their shantytown and to try to start again.

Who will eat the most food? Who will wear the least tattered clothes? Who will live in the finest hovel? Who will become The Mayor of Hooverville?

20928.name: Long Winding Road
20928.description:
Long Winding Road provides the chance to run a full season's Marathon Championship with the 141 men and 78 women each running 6 races during the year. You can choose from over 40 courses together with their Weather Modifiers. A Championship season of 12 races for men and 10 for women is suggested, so with each race taking about 2 1/2 hours playing time such a season would take around 60 hours to complete - well within the realms of possibility for many replay gamers if feedback from you is anything to go by.

The aim has been to try to recreate the way in which actual Marathon events develop, with small groups of runners breaking away off the front of the main pack, and others losing ground off the back.

We recommend 40 to 70 starters, although the system can cope with larger numbers if necessary, and we deal with the race in 1 kilometer stages, so it would not be sensible or enjoyable to require a dice roll for every competitor each kilometer. With a field of 70 that would entail around 3000 dice rolls!

So we only concern ourselves with identifying those runners within each Group (in game terms a Group consists of any number of runners from one upwards occupying a single 10-second space of our Endless Track) who need their Rating checked for that particular kilometer of the race to see whether they stay with their present Group, or make a forward or backward movement - that is gain or lose around 10 seconds on their Group over this kilometer.

National, European, Commonwealth, and Asian Championships can be run within the context of the main season's Championship, plus a Team Championship on a race-by-race or full season basis.

20929.name: Booktastic! Family Edition
20929.description:
Booktastic!
Family Edition
for ages 10 and up
Features Children's Literature!

Booktastic is a fun-for-the-whole-family game that combines traditional strategic and competitive play with the sharing of literary trivia! Booktastic appeals to rudimentary readers, bookish braniacs, and everyone in between. Because the casual reader questions are opinion-based and have no wrong answers, anyone can play including children and non-readers. During the game players move around a quaint town square of bookstores to buy, sell, and trade books according to a collection card they receive at the beginning of the game. Before each turn, players earn money by choosing question cards. The player with the most valuable collection of books and cash at the end of the game wins!

20931.name: Borderline
20931.description:
An abstract strategy game where the object is to reach the other side of the board (or take all your opponents pieces).

The game takes place on a 6x9 grid and each player has 12 pieces. Each piece is quartered and each quarter numbered from 1 to 4. This indicates the number of spaces that piece must move in that direction. Opponents pieces are taken by moving over them (jumping) or by landing on them.

20932.description:
The players place their pieces on a central board trying to recreate the constellation patterns that appear on their cards in order to win.

The game comes with a cloth board, 20 double-sided wooden cylinders and 2 black cylinders (used for blocking board positions).
20932.name: Zoodiak

20933.name: Encontro Marcado
20933.description: Each player must avoid the other player on a labyrinth. Every time you make your move, you influence the other player decision for the next move. The one that reaches the center first is the winner.

20934.name: Pavia 1525
20934.description: The battles of Pavia: France against Spain for the control of Italy.

20935.name: Magikon
20935.description:
Magikon is a simple Role Playing Game published in Italian + French only by International Team in 1984.
The guide to encounters includes 22 different kind of people with illustrations made by Mauro Moretti.
The background: Every 1000 years, the shadow master organizes a competition between magician-knights to chose who will succeed to him as governor of the Magikon castle and the surrounding region.
The players will explore the roads around the castle to find monsters, traps and villages. Every player has the same kind of background, so the team working is not necessary and usually, each player explores different areas.

20936.name: The Space Game
20936.description:
A game of interstellar trade and conquest. Players explore new worlds, make deals with resources, build fleets and do battle with their fleets, with agents or on the market. Each turn you may:
1.Place a piece
2.Move your ships and/or place agents
3.Bribe stars (to conquer them), battle over stars or build ships.
The object of the game is to be the last surviving player or the player with the most stars and resources wins.

20938.name: Dicefest
20938.description:
Dicefest is a strategic, abstract board game for two, three or four players who must manipulate their dice and get them to the other side of the board to win. Players will need to think and plan ahead to gain ground. Knowing how to maneuver the dice efficiently while blocking your opponents’ moves are important elements to winning.

Dicefest is available here;
http://www.geocities.com/roujin27/dicefest.html

20939.name: Puzzle Train
20939.description:
Puzzle Train

Puzzle Train is a boardgame 'German type' (puzzle slide-game) for 4 players design by José Carlos de Diego Guerrero, based in Puzzle Railroad pc-game by XD Games and it is a crossover of Mississippi Queen and Carcassonne.

This game was published in the magazine Tabula #6 (in Spanish).

Links:

Review in Revista Tabula #6 (in Spanish)
http://www.labsk.net/index.php?topic=127.0

Download (in Spanish, previous register)
http://www.labsk.net/index.php?topic=143.0

20940.name: Operation Warboard
20940.description: An entry level tabletop wargame, that in fact has a greater level of detail than most "beginner" rule sets. Taking the approach of low cost gaming, the pictures and diagrams all depict ways to cut costs and begin gaming, and as such tends to relegate this rule set to a "beginner" level. Set as a platoon or company level engagement, the rules have a unique MG grid to infantry fire resolution. A good example of "low detail" for those that are "painting" impaired.

20941.name: All For One
20941.description:
France, 1630. The Royal Musketeers are personal guards of King Louis XIII, defending the King against the dubious plots of Cardinal Richelieu. Athos, Porthos, Aramis, d'Artagnan, Rochefort, and MiLady DiWinter move around Paris, fighting duels and completing missions to earn the favor of the King and Cardinal. Both characters and players earn Favors throughout the game and bonus points are scored at the end when players reveal their true allegiances. The winner is the player who's earned the most Favor!

All For One is a pickup/deliver game for 3-5 players. Players are not tied to any specific character, rather each turn you choose which character to activate and then take actions with that character. Each player is secretly assigned one of the characters whose score will be added to their own at the end of the game. Your 'secret identity' helps drive decisions during the game, but in order to win you'll have to utilize all of the characters.

The board is an interconnected web of streets, some of which are patrolled by Cardinal's Guards. The guards serve to hinder the musketeers' progress. There are 6 named locations where the characters begin the game, and the other 18 locations are home to 1 plot token each. 2 of the tokens are horses, which can be ridden by the characters. The rest are used to complete missions.

The missions are printed on Mission Cards, which detail which character must complete the mission, which Plot Tokens are necessary to complete the mission, and the location at which the mission must be completed. Completing these missions involves collecting various Plot Tokens from around the board, and bringing them to specific places. Some missions involve getting 2 of the characters to a specific place at the same time, and some missions involve a duel between two characters.

20942.name: Amnesia: The Short-Term Memory Game.
20942.description:
From the Publisher's Instructions Sheet:

Amnesia is a short-term memory game where you can score if you remember ... and score if you forget. To WIN, just start on START and make it around your triangle to the center of the board.

20943.name: Arcadia
20943.description:
A tile-laying and -stacking game, a basic set consists of 40 hexagonal tiles worth different numbers of points. The tile are ridged so that three tiles together can form a base for a fourth tile to sit upon them.

Gameplay consists of playing tiles from a "hand" of three tiles. Tiles laid on top of other tiles are required to have the same pattern inscribed on them as the tile making up their base. Tiles placed above the first level score depending on the point value of the tile played and the level it was played on .

Sets come in a single color, and different sets come in different colors, allowing for expansion and more advanced play in which color also becomes a factor for scoring.

20944.name: Holding
20944.description:
The financial game of Chinese boxes.
The target of the game is to acquire the absolute majority (160)of the shares. You must go around the board collecting shares and creating new societies and holding companies. Four circuits around four countries give different risk features and you have to manage black funds, bankruptcy, transfers of capital, purchase of shares and the majority of companies. The movement on the board is made by dice rolling.

Note: it is strongly suspected that this game is identical to Capital Power. But until someone can compare the two boxes and their contents, we should keep two entries in the database.

20945.name: Probaddility
20945.description: Probaddility is an engaging card game dealing with probability and simple addition. Players make educated bets about the likely numbers hidden under opponents cards and win or lose cards depending on the accuracy of their predictions. A fun and engaging introduction to these basic concepts.

20946.name: Real Numbers
20946.description: The REAL NUMBERS game was designed as a prelude to EQUATIONS. It comes in a handy 5-game kit that can be clipped to a pen in your shirt pocket. The REAL NUMBERS Game provides a practical introduction to the process of finding Solutions from randomly generated symbols similar to what occurs in EQUATIONS. The REAL NUMBERS Game deals with real, rational, irrational, integer, and natural numbers.

20947.name: Lady Oscar
20947.description: Children game based on the Italian version of a popular Japanese cartoon (The Rose of Versailles, called "Lady Oscar" in Italy).

20948.name: The Meditation Game
20948.description:
From Publisher:

THE MEDITATION GAME offers a delightful excursion into the realm of pure strategy. Though simple in design, the game is rich in creative possibilities and subtle surprises. The colorful playing mat and 49 playing rings are used by two players or teams in the pursuit of “Spontaneous Right Action”. Clear, coherent and comprehensive thought is required for success. THE MEDITATION GAME offers people of all ages a refreshing opportunity to experience a gentle, mental massage.

20949.name: UNO: Batman Begins
20949.description:
Based on the 2005 Batman Begins movie.

WHAT MAKES IT DIFFERENT FROM TRADITIONAL UNO: The Special Justice Card. ???

20950.description:
Gazala-Tobruk game system, of medium complexity, puts the emphasis on armored combat, with tank/armor units at battalion level and regiments and brigades for the infantry. Each type of unit exerts a type of ZoC depending of the quantity and/or quality of its anti tank/armor assets, from rigid ZoC to semi rigid or no ZoC at all.

Other outstanding aspects of the rules are the HQ units that give combat support (There are HQ at the Army, Corps, Division levels, and even at Brigade level for independent British Armored brigades); minefields, air support and Allied redoubts or boxes.
20950.name: Gazala-Tobruk

20951.name: Mimikri
20951.description:
Mimikri can be played as two variants of traditional chess.

In the first, players know the identity their own pieces but not that of their opponent. Only by studying the opponent's moves, can the pieces be identified.

In the second variant, players know the identity of their opponent's pieces but not of their own. Moves are made blindly. If a player moves a piece inappropriately, the opposing player says "no," the piece is returned to its original position and it becomes the opposing player's turn to move. However, if the move is appropriate, the piece remains in its new position thus revealing its identity. Subsequent moves can be made accordingly. It is now the opposing player's turn to move.

20952.description:
Uno for children Ages 3 and up.

Players are dealt 5 cards, the rest forming a draw pile. The first card from the draw pile is turned over and players take turns matching the top card in the discard pile. Cards can match by number, color or animal. A player who can't match a card must draw from the draw pile. A player must call "UNO" once he is down to a single card. A player who fails to do so and is challenged by another player must draw 2 cards.

The first player to get rid of all his cards wins.

Components:
56 cards
Instructions

Instead of numbers (in the classical version) the cards show some animals and some cards are missing.
boardgameversion: GDW Games 2 for 1 Nordic edition with UNO
20952.name: UNO Junior

boardgamehonor: 2006 Deutscher Lernspielpreis "6 years and up" Nominee
2006 Deutscher Lernspielpreis "6 years and up" Winner
2006 Spiel der Spiele Hit für Kinder Recommended
20953.description: Set the sails and weigh the anchor! Several pirate ships cruise the seas in Piratissimo on the lookout for precious hidden treasure. It's a matter of honor to discover it, load it on board, and be the first to bring it into the harbor – despite competition from the other pirates, tornadoes, and the seal of fate. The pirates are none too friendly: they steal, plunder, and sink ships wherever they can. But too much greed can put their pirate treasure at stake. An absolutely merciless game for the whole family. Board, or be boarded!
20953.name: Piratissimo

20954.name: Alpen Express
20954.description:
Alpen Express is a game that uses a system of trains to move your people from the crowded city to the verdant Alps. The players roll a die and can move one train to the matching number. Each player can must move one pawn off or on the moved train.

The goal is to have all of your people jump from train to train toward the center of the board. Sometimes you can't help but aid others, but more times than not if you aren't helping yourself you get the opportunity to block out other player's chance for success.

This is billed as a kids game, but it also works as a nice opener/closer for adults. As this is made from solid wood with working wooden trains, it doesn't make for the most portable filler.

20956.name: Civil War Wit
20956.description:
A simple trivia game covering the American Civil War. Each card (two standard decks' worth) has a photograph or etching reproduction on the front and a point value. On the back are two questions--one "buff" level, the other "scholar" level. Get either question right--it's not clear, from the rules, who gets to choose which question gets asked, the asker or the answerer--and you get the points listed on the card. There is often no clear connection between the point value of the question and its difficulty. The pictures, however, are very nice.

In an odd twist, if a card's question goes unanswered, the answer is then read aloud and the card set aside. After all the rest of the cards have been dealt with, this pile of discards--whose answers, again, have been revealed--gets shuffled up and gone through again. Presumably this is to test short-term memory. The game ends once all cards have been correctly answered.

This is part of a series of "WIT" games from this company, which included trivia games on wildlife, National Parks, and other Americana topics.

20957.name: Asesinato en el Orient Express
20957.description:
A murder has happened on the Orient Express train. There are 12 characters, the suspects. One player moves the characters around a map of Europe, and he is the only one to know the identity of the killer.
Each of the other players leads a team of 3 detectives around Europe, accomplishing missions that give them clues about the killer's identity, while the killer tries to mislead them.
The detective teams must cooperate, but remembering that only one player will be the winner. If the killer has not been discovered after the set time limit (between 1 and 2 hours), he wins.

20958.name: Word Fun
20958.description:
The rules for two different games are included in the box.

One, Two, Three - Go! (for 3-4 players)

Object of the Game
Each player competes with others to collect as many 3 card sets as quickly as possible.

Rules:
1. Place all cards scattered face up in the center of the group.
2. On a count of three, each player begins to collect his cards. First a lead card must be picked; then its idea related partners. a 3 card set must be completed before a player may start again, picking a lead card first.
3. After all cards have been collected and assembled in 3 card sets, the player with the most card sets wins!

Letter Recognition (for 2-5 players)

Object of the Game
To group by the first letter of the first word on each card, while trying to lay down all cards. The first player out of cards wins.

Rules:
1. Shuffle cards, one player deals all cards equally to each player.
2. Each player should organize their cards, grouping like letters. Example: Post Office, Park, Picnic Table, etc.
3. The dealer starts play by laying down the first card. Play continues clockwise with each child laying down a card that begins with the same letter as led by the dealer.
4. If a player cannot play a card he "passes," and play continues to the next player.
5. If all players have laid down all cards beginning with that same letter, the last player to lay down starts the next group.
6. Play continues and the first player to lay down all his carsd wins!

Recommended for Ages 4 - 8.

20959.description:
From the rules:

Once, the small village of Port Dover, situated on the north shore of Lake Erie, harboured the world's largest fresh water fishing fleet. Now, become one of the local captains deploying fishing tugboats and vying for the precious freshwater fish.

Essentially, a set collecting / stock manipulation game, players collect "fish" or cubes in 5 different colors. To collect fish, you send out your boats to one of five ponds. Usually, when you dispatch a boat to a pond, you change a fishes vaule and move a fish to a different pond. After three rounds, players score for the value of any fish type for which they have the majority.

Very fast playing, published and distributed for free at Great Lakes Games III.
20959.name: Port Dover

20960.name: Dumb Luck the Ultimate Gambling Party Game
20960.description:
Dumb Luck is the Ultimate Gambling Party game, which combines poker, blackjack, hi-lo, and 19 other exciting games of chance with a race to the finish line where the winner cleans out what is left in the bank.

The Dumb Luck game is even set up as a "$20 buy in" if playing for some friendly cash is desired (and allowed). Among the many pieces included are 300 11.5 gram poker chips, 3 decks of cards, 8 dice, custom spinner, full color hinged board, and a beautiful locking carrying case. Take a look at www.dumbluckgame.com

20961.name: Musical Bingo
20961.description:
Each player gets a musical bingo card. The cards consist of a diamond of whole, half, quarter, eighth, and sixteenth notes distributed across the two musical clefs (treble and bass). Each card either has notes on the lines or notes on the spaces between the lines. The placement of the high/low notes are staggered and each card has a different placement of the various note lengths.

The caller selects one of the musical note chits, which have a particular pitch and duration. Players check their boards to see if they can match that pitch and duration. If they can, they place a marker on the appropriate note. Play continues until someone can make a run of 5 notes.

20962.name: Metropolitan Washington Trivia
boardgamepublisher: Washington D.C. Trivia Playing Cards Inc.
20962.description:
This Trivial Pursuit clone has cards with six categories: People, Politics, Places, Culture/Entertainment, Fine Points, and Sports. The questions relate to the Washington D.C. area.

The included instructions have players take turns rolling a die (not included) and answering a question in the corresponding category. Answering two questions correctly in a row gives the player one "letter" marker (a piece of cut-out paper). Once you have gotten 10 letter markers (spelling WASHINGTON) you win.

The rules also state that the cards "can be used with other trivia game boards - just use our colors instead of theirs."

boardgamehonor: 2007 Golden Geek Best Board Game Artwork/Presentation Nominee
2007 Golden Geek Best Gamer's Board Game Nominee
2008 JoTa Best Cooperative Board Game Nominee
20963.description:
In Fury of Dracula, a game of Gothic adventure, one player takes the role of Dracula while up to four others attempt to stop him by controlling Vampire hunters from the famous Bram Stoker novel.

Dracula has returned, and is determined to control all of Europe by creating an undead empire of Vampires. Dracula uses a deck of location cards to secretly travel through Europe, leaving a trail of encounters and events for the hunters that chase him.

Meanwhile, the hunters attempt to track and destroy Dracula using the limited information available to them - a task easier said than done when their prey has the power to change forms into a wolf or bat, and can even melt away into the mist when confronted.

To save Europe and rid the world of Dracula's foul plague, the hunters must destroy Dracula before he earns enough victory points to win the game... will they have enough wit and bravery to defeat the dark count?
20963.name: Fury of Dracula (second edition)
boardgamepodcastepisode: 5. Something To Sink Your Teeth Into? Fury of Dracula Reviewed
Allt på ett kort #16 – Fury of Dracula
AP Podcast – Episodio 8: La Furia de Drácula
BGWS 016 – The Fury of Dracula
Diogenes Digital 2x16: Vampiros, Castlevania y La furia de Drácula
Episode 25:  Clash of Cultures Review - Top 10s with Jamie Keagy of The Secret Cabal
Episode 29: Fury of Dracula, Horror Board Games and Dungeon Master Cheating
Episode 99.99–Game Buffet you Traitorous Dog!
Episodio 11 – Especial verano 2013: Juegos no jugados
ET62: Dracula en las trincheras con el casco prusiano
Podcast #112 - Piterpanes de 40
The Messy Game Room Episode 4
The Vintage Gamer #12: (The) Fury of Dracula (BG)
What Did You Play This Week Podcast Thing Week 52!!! The Anniversary Episode featuring EVERYONE!!

20964.name: The Game of States and Cities
20964.description:
The cards in this game contain a map side and a question side. The map side contains a map of the United States with a state blackened in. The question side has the name of a state and 6 questions about the state (state flowers, topographical features, capitals etc.).

There are two games to play. The first involves players looking at the map sides of the cards and making guesses as to which state is blackened in. If they are correct they score the card. If they are wrong it goes to the bottom of their card stack. The second game involves players asking the trivia questions and the other players answering (each player gets one guess and the the players are asked in order around the table). If you answer correctly you get the card. If no one answers a question you ask, you get that card. Most cards win.

The game is covered by U.S. patent 1745946.

20965.name: Der Natur auf der Spur
20965.description: Your adventure takes you from the tree house to the dock at the pond. Along the way you try to correctly answer as many questions about the plant and animal worlds as possible. For every correct answer, and for landing on environmentally friendly spaces, you receive point chips. You lose points for landing on environmentally unfriendly spaces. You may also gain points by successfully rolling to acquire all the parts to a five piece butterfly puzzle. Whoever has collected the most points when the first player reaches the dock is the winner.

20966.name: Queen of the Cupcakes
20966.description:
From the publisher's website (Refers to the First Edition titled "King of the Beasts"):

A Royal Card Game by Reiner Knizia
The mythological animals are battling to see who is the ultimate King of the Beasts. The dragon is the largest, the kraken is the strongest, the unicorn is the most enchanting, and the manticore and the gryphon are powerful in their own rights. Even the tiny fire salamander wants to be King! But who will win the most votes?

Gain as many points as possible by nominating animals to be King, while still keeping some of the cards for your score pile. Once an animal becomes King, points are awarded - the player with the most points wins!

20967.description:
La sombra del Aguila (Shadow of the Eagle) rules are a consolidation of the game system that appeared in Alea Magazine issue 16. With a basic rules and advanced rules.

It includes three scenarios:

Alcañiz 1809,
Maria 1809
Castalla 1813.
20967.name: La sombra del aguila
boardgamefamily: The Shadow of the Eagle: Series

20969.name: Lomby Zombie
20969.description:
A tile-based, tactical, roleplaying game with a touch of humor. Players fight their way to clear out and secure a house from an ever increasing horde of zombies.

A zombie master creates a house using sets of tiles that players explore. Players allocate statistics to create a character for their play style.

Each round, a new event occurs that affects an aspect of the game is played.

20970.name: Hearts Card Game
20970.description: This game comes with a special 44-card deck with pictures of animals. Players try to avoid taking raccoon cards which are negative points. Play is faster than Hearts since the deck is smaller. The scoring and play rules are also simplified for children.

20972.name: Dr. Kildare
20972.description:
Medical game for kids Ages 7 - 12. Based on the TV show of the same name. Players make rounds in the hospital diagnosing patients.

Contents include: game board, four pawns, spinner, "analyzer", 11 red doctor cards, 40 blue doctor cards, 39 diagnosis cards, and instructions.

20973.name: The Game of Yertle
20973.description:
A balancing game of skill based on the popular book by Dr. Seuss. Based on their spin, players must place Yertles on a balanced plate without causing them to all fall down!

Contents includes: Tumbler, spinner, 21 Yertles. (Instructions came printed inside the box top.)

20975.name: Would You Believe?
20975.description:
Contents: Six pawns, score card, answer cards, question cards, and the instructions.

Object: Move up and back down the score card by the use of the move values on the question cards. Be the first to arrive back at start.

20976.name: Operation: Sealion 1940
20976.description:
From the web-site description:
"It is the year 1940. France has surrendered. The British and the remains of the French Army have retreated across the English Channel. Germany now controls the whole of Western Europe. The United Kingdom stands alone, waiting for the Germans to strike. Hitler approves plans for an upcoming invasion of the United Kingdom. A plan called Operation: SEALION. The invasion of the United Kingdom is about to begin!"

This follows in the same vein as some other 'Battle' GAME based upon the "Axis & Allies" series, while you'll need to procure the necessary 'bits' from one of those to play this. There are entirely NEW components made up for this, with "Order of Battle" charts, the 'Gamemap', and with '3' SETs(or 'kinds') of CARDs for use in it.

20977.name: Powerplay: The Game of Knowledge and Strategy
20977.description:
POWERPLAY is a question and answer game of political and social issues. The questions are based on 5 categories (committees): War, Environment, Commerce, State (International politics and policies), and Domestic Policy (U.S. policies and public opinions). There is a range difficulty from "lots of people know this" to "Wow! I didn't know that." More difficult questions have multiple choice answers and higher point (vote) value. Using political reasoning and/or logic can yield a correct answer even when it is not initially known.
The board for POWERPLAY resembles a Senate chamber. Players are "Senators". Each player/team gets a "Committee Table". The object of the game is to correctly answer questions in each category to gain "Committee Seats" as well as more votes than your opponents.
Strategies that can be used include:

answering multiple choice questions correctly before the answers are read gives the player double the votes for that question
censuring an opponent sends them to the censure room where they cannot answer questions to gain Committee Seats or votes
filibustering allows a player to remove votes from their opponents
players can remove opponents from Committees on which they have already gained a seat
players that have a Seat on every Committee have a choice: either allow their opponents to chose the category for the next question and automatically win with a correct answer or continue playing and maintaining control over which category questions will be answered.




POWERPLAY game pieces are made of wood.

20978.name: Geo-Graphy
20978.description:
Object: To peg-in as many places beginning with the letter indicated by the alphabet dial as the timer allows.

Components: Peg map board of the world, sand timer, alphabet dial, pegs, and instructions (printed inside box top).

20979.name: Howdy Doody's TV Game
20979.description:
A visit to Howdy's own TV studio! Players spin the "Howdy Doody Time" spinner then move their pieces through the studio visiting the show's characters and scenes.

Components: Game board, spinner, 6 character pawns (color cardboard stand-ups of show characters), 6 wooden pawn stands, 4 wooden movers.

20981.name: Silly Sidney
20981.description:
The absent-minded elephant game. Based on the Silly Sidney character from the Hector Heathcote Show. Players travel through the jungle to find their animal friends.

Contents: 14 cards, 4 pawns, game board, spinner, instructions.

20983.name: Fourcast
20983.description:
Four games of destiny: Taro reading, astrological casting, questions oracle, and numberology chart. Explore your past, present, and future. Fourcast combines four of the most respected occult methods of divination and fortune telling with games of skill and chance for your amusement and instruction.

Contents: 42 taro cards, six special instruction cards, astrology tally pad, numberology chart pad, fortune formula pad, oracle pendulum, answer board, and the instructions.

20984.description:
Game found in Alea Magazine #25. Uses Thirty Year War Quad rules to simulate the battles of Las Dunas (Spanish Tercios against a Franco-English army).

Expands

Thirty Years War (first edition)
20984.name: Las Dunas 1658

20985.description:
Game found in Alea Magazine #25 along with Las Dunas 1658. Uses the Thirty Years War Quad rules to simulate the battle fought out near Montjuich castle in Barcelona pitting the Spanish Tercios against a Catalan Rebel force supported by some French units.

Expands

Thirty Years War (first edition)
20985.name: Montjuic 1641

20986.name: The Flintstones Stoneage Game
20986.description:
The game that rocked Bedrock! Players search Bedrock and collect sets of cards with characters, locations, or objects (Fred's Car) from the show.

Includes game board, 4 scoring pegs, game cards, and instructions.

20987.name: Scroll
20987.description:
The board is 11 spaces square. The outer squares are not used except for the corner ‘home base’ squares. In the center is a 3 square x 3 square scroll zone, which includes four 'sleeping men'. Each player starts with nine counters. These may be moved either 1 or 4 squares each turn in a straight line in any direction but may not jump over any other pieces. Pieces are captured if they are sandwiched between two pieces of one other player of if the piece becomes the third piece in a diagonal formation. Captured pieces entitle a player to reclaim pieces previously lost.

There are three levels of winning. Basic - by eliminating all of your opponent's pieces. A scroll win - make the scroll zone entirely your color. A Grand scroll - make the scroll zone entirely your color, but without using your sleeping man.

20988.name: Bible Tit Tat Toe
20988.description:
Stimulating, entertaining, and educational with 1,000 questions and answers in regular and advanced format. Players answer questions about the Bible to win squares on the "Tit Tat Toe" board.

Contents: Tit Tat Toe board, 10 playing squares, 500 question cards, instructions.

20989.name: Krusade
20989.description: In Krusade you roll dice to move along a track (there are a variety of paths to choose from). If you land on some spaces you collect a polyomino from a set of 18. Once you have collected 18 polyominos, you choose a challenge card and you need to use the polyominoes to create the pattern on the challenge card to win the game. While you are trying to solve the puzzle, the other players continue to play. Various locations on the board have different effects such as "return all your pieces and start again", "take a piece from every player", or "swap seats with any player".

20990.name: Off To See The Wizard
20990.description:
Children scaled board game where children stand in as pawns.

Each player takes his place ate the beginning of his path, He must always move forward the number of steps indicated by the spinner, following the Yellow Brick Road. Obey the signs on each brick. If a a player is in another player's way, you cannot pass him. If a player has been instructed, though, to go to a space already occupied, the more than one player can occupy the space together. The first player to land on the Gate to Oz must spin a number one to enter and win.

20991.name: The Battle of Bentonville
20991.description:
This self published wargame was developed in the late 1970's and published in 1980. Designed by Eric D. France, developed by Michael Scott and printed by Dixie Press in Gulfport, MS. This was a limited edition, only a thousand copies, depicting the last large land battle of the American Civil War.

Subtitled Johnston's Last Stand, The Battle of Bentonville has large, oversized counters for the introductory game. There is a roster sheet for both the Union and Confederate armies. There is also a roll up hex based board that is flexible (much like the portable chess boards used in tournaments.

There are both introductory and advanced rules, as well as smaller,traditional sized counters for the advanced version. A historical commentary booklet is also included.

20992.name: Whoops!
20992.description:
Everybody plays on every spin! Spin the spinner, do the stunt, squeak the squeaker, tag out, and win!

Contents: Game board, spinner, squeaker, scoring pegs, scoreboard.

20993.name: Bicycle Official Rules of Card Games
boardgamepublisher: The United States Playing Card Company
20993.description:
Rules for over 250 card games, including numerous Poker variants. Includes other classics such as Spades, Hearts, Bridge, Bid Whist, Pinochle, Rummy, Canasta, Solitaire, Cribbage, childrens card games, "and many more!" Includes a 17 page glossary of card game terms. Illustrated.

90th edition printed in 2003. 338 pages. $7.99 cover price.

This is the new version of Official Rules of Card Games. This title includes the "Bicycle" name in the header. "Bicycle" cards are produced by the The United States Playing Card Company, which publishes both this book and its predecessor Official Rules of Card Games. This new book also has a new editor Joli Quentin Kansil.

20994.name: Tagina 552 d.c.
20994.description: The battle of Taginae (552) between Goths and Byzantine during Byzantine reconquest of the Italian Peninsula.

20996.name: Duellen
20996.description:
One player is black, the other white. The board is has 7x15 squares. Each player has 17 pieces with values from 1 to 6 in addition to a heart piece, which has a value of 1. Each piece can move diagonally or orthogonally up to the number on it. A piece can take an opponents piece by moving exactly as far as the number on it. One can place two pieces on top of each other, the double piece can then move a distance equal to the sum. A player wins when the opponents heart piece is captured or pieces with a total of 40 or more is captured.

(Translated from the box - in Norwegian)
Duell
Suggested age: 9 years
Production number: 15628

Duell is fought out between two duelists on 105 squares that marks the battlefield. Each player have 18 pieces, of which one is the heart piece. The one who hits the opponents heart piece or knocks out a combined value of 40 of the opponents pieces, wins the game.

Contents:
Game board
2 x 18 pieces
Game rules

20997.name: Funny Finger
20997.description:
Funny Fingers everywhere, sticking out here and there! Match each finger one by one, Funny Finger is funny fun!

Players match up other players' fingers (sticking through holes in the finger fence).

Contents: Four finger fences, scoreboard, scoring pegs, instructions (inside lid).

20998.name: Solferino 24 Giugno 1859
20998.description:
Big game over the battle of Solferino.
Battalion/squadron level, 1700 counters, two maps, 9 game tables, rules and scenarios folders.
Linking with San Martino 24 Giugno 1859

20999.name: San Martino 24 Giugno 1859
20999.description:
A game over the battle of San Martino.
Battalion/squadron level, 500 counters, one map, 9 game tables, rules and scenarios folders.
Linking with Solferino 24 Giugno 1859

21000.name: Naughty Dogs
21000.description:
"As the clothes go out to dry in the sun, naughty dogs steal them... just for fun!"

Naughty Dogs is a children's game for two to four players, ages four and up. The game consists of a clockwork powered clothes line that rotates and four dogs that leap up when a paddle is pressed (or hit). The four colors are red, blue, green and yellow.

To set up, you attach 12 articles of clothing to the washing line, three of each color of pants, shirt and socks (in increasing order of difficulty), wind up the mechanism and let it go. The clothes line spins and the players hit the paddles to make their dog leap up to grab the clothing.

The winner of the game is the person the highest score. you get 10 points for pants, 15 for the tee-shirt and 20 for the socks in your color. Each article of clothing your dog gets that isn't in your color costs you 30 points, so it pays to be a bit careful.

A warning to parents... This is quite a noisy game to play, but each game only lasts for about two minutes.
